bestBHT.bht: The state of the heart is the true measure for admission to the visible Church. God, who knows the hearts, bore witness to the sincerity of these Gentiles by giving them the Holy Spirit. This act was the work of the Lord, showing His acceptance of them. The Eternal, who sees the secrets of all hearts, judged their genuineness. Thus, circumcision was not necessary for salvation, and God's endorsement of the Gentiles through the gift of the Holy Spirit confirmed their acceptance into the Church.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the real question for admission to full standing in the visible Church is the state of the heart.
no principle of admission to church privileges which reverses this can be sound.
Albert Barnes: And God, which knoweth the hearts - Acts 1:24. God thus knew whether they were true converts or not.
and gave a demonstration that he acknowledged them as his.
Giving them the Holy Ghost ... - Acts 10:45-46.
Marvin Vincent: Which knoweth the heart [καρδιογνωστης] . Only here and ch. 1 24.
Philip Schaff: And God, which knoweth the hearts, bare them witness, giving them the Holy Ghost, even as he did unto us."
The Eternal, before whom the secrets of all hearts are open, was able to judge of the sincerity of these Gentiles."
He testified that these hitherto despised strangers were acceptable in His sight by giving them the Holy Ghost, just as He had done to the Jews who had turned and believed in Jesus.
John Gill: And God which knoweth the hearts... knew with what sincerity Cornelius sent for Peter."
God bore a testimony, and showed his well pleasedness in the whole of this affair.
Circumcision was not necessary to salvation.
John Wesley: God bare them witness — That he had accepted them, by giving them the Holy Ghost.

bhtAttempts.bht: The state of the heart is the true measure of admission to the visible Church. No principle of admission that contradicts this can be valid. God, who knows the hearts, knew whether these Gentiles were true converts, and He bore witness to their sincerity by giving them the Holy Spirit. This act was the work of the Lord, showing His acceptance of them, just as He had done with the Jews. The Eternal, who sees the secrets of all hearts, was able to judge their genuineness. Thus, circumcision was not a requirement for salvation, and God's endorsement of the Gentiles through the gift of the Holy Spirit was a clear confirmation of their acceptance into the Church.

In determining admission to the visible Church, the state of the heart is the crucial factor. Any principle that contradicts this is unsound. God, being the knower of hearts, accurately discerns their true nature. He gave the Gentiles the Holy Spirit, indicating His acceptance of them, just as He did for the Jews. By this, the Eternal demonstrated His ability to judge their sincerity. Therefore, circumcision is not a prerequisite for salvation, and the bestowal of the Holy Spirit confirms the Gentiles' acceptance into the Church.
